marketNews.title: Gerindra daily chairman says President Prabowo has no cabinet reshuffle plan
marketNews.content: Daily chairman of the Gerindra Party, Sufmi Dasco Ahmad, said that President Prabowo Subianto has no plan to conduct a cabinet reshuffle in the near future, including the position of finance minister currently held by Sri Mulyani. Previously, there were rumors that Sri Mulyani would resign from her post. Sri Mulyani herself refused to comment on the issue.

marketNews.title: Reuters consensus expects BI Rate to stay at 5.75% on March 19 meeting
marketNews.content: A consensus of economists compiled by Reuters expects Bank Indonesia to keep the BI Rate at 5.75% in the Governor Board meeting on Wednesday, March 19, to protect the rupiah from further depreciation amid escalating global trade wars.

marketNews.title: Indonesia trade surplus rises to $3.12 billion in February 2025
marketNews.content: BPS reported that Indonesia's trade surplus increased to $3.12 billion in February 2025 (versus $0.833 billion in February 2024 and $3.45 billion in January 2025), surpassing the consensus estimate of $2.45 billion. The result was driven by export growth of 14.05% year‑on‑year (versus 4.68% in January 2025), beating the consensus of 9.1% YoY and marking the highest growth since January 2023. Imports grew only 2.3% YoY (versus a decline of 2.73% in January 2025, consensus 0.6% YoY).

marketNews.title: Ministry of Energy sets coal price at $117.76 per ton for second half of March 2025
marketNews.content: The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources set the Coal Reference Price (HBA) at $117.76 per ton for the second half of March 2025, an 8.2% decline from the first half of March 2025 price of $128.24 per ton. The HBA serves as the reference price for coal exports starting 1 March 2025 and is revised twice a month. Previously, the implementation of HBA as an export reference price was expected to dampen demand from China because the HBA is relatively higher than the global benchmark prices.

marketNews.title: Transport Minister says truck operation restrictions will remain March 24‑April 8 2025
marketNews.content: Transport Minister Dudy Purwagandhi said the government will continue to impose restrictions on goods‑truck operations from 24 March to 8 April 2025, despite truck operators threatening large protests. The restriction aims to prevent traffic congestion during the Lebaran home‑coming period. The chairman of the Indonesian Truck Owners Association, Gemilang Tarigan, said truck operators agreed not to operate on 20 March 2025 if the government does not revise the ban period.

tickerNews.title: Bank Central Asia reports net profit of 4.2 trillion IDR in February 2025
tickerNews.content:
Bank Central Asia (BBCA) recorded net profit (bank only) of 4.2 trillion rupiah in February 2025 (+12% YoY, -10% MoM). This result made the net profit for the first two months of 2025 (2M25) grow 8.4% YoY to 9 trillion rupiah, beating the 2025 consolidated consensus estimate of 7% YoY growth. On the positive side, BBCA reported a decline in credit cost (CoC) in February 2025. On the downside, liquidity tightened and Net Interest Margin (NIM) remained low.

- CoC fell after a high in January 2025: bank‑only CoC dropped to 0.05% in February 2025 (vs. 0.76% in January 2025, 0.57% in February 2024). This recovery brought the 2M25 CoC level down to 0.4% (vs. 0.43% in 2M24), still above the 2025 consolidated guidance of 0.3%.
- Liquidity tightened, though still ample: bank‑only credit growth slowed to +14% YoY in 2M25 (vs. +15.1% YoY in 1M25 and 2M24). The slowdown aligns with management’s target of consolidated credit growth of 6‑8% YoY for 2025. Meanwhile, third‑party funds (DPK) remained flat at +3.9% YoY in 2M25 (vs. +3.9% YoY in 1M25 and +5.1% YoY in 2M24). This dynamic pushed the Loan‑to‑Deposit Ratio (LDR) back above 80%, reaching 80.6% in 2M25 (vs. 79.7% in 1M25 and 73.5% in 2M24). Although higher LDR is an industry‑wide issue, BBCA still enjoys relatively good liquidity compared with other “Big 4” banks.
- NIM lowest since February 2024: bank‑only NIM was 5.4% in February 2025 (vs. 5.33% in February 2024, 5.91% in January 2025), the lowest since February 2024. Consequently, 2M25 NIM stood at 5.67% (vs. 5.52% in 2M24), slightly below the 2025 consolidated guidance range of 5.7‑5.8%. Interest income growth was modest at 7.1 trillion rupiah (+4.8% YoY, -7.6% MoM), the main factor behind the low NIM in February 2025. By comparison, annual interest income growth was around 7‑8% YoY in Q4 2024. Nevertheless, Net Interest Income (NII) still grew modestly, reaching +6% YoY in February 2025 and 2M25, supported by low interest expense. Loan yield improvement is part of BBCA’s management intent for the year. Pre‑provision Operating Profit (PPOP) grew +8.6% YoY in 2M25, aided by relatively efficient operating expenses (OPEX) that rose only +3.5% YoY.

Key Takeaway: We assess BBCA’s bank‑only performance in February 2025 as mixed because CoC fell but NIM remained low. However, we believe NIM can recover, driven by potential interest‑rate cuts and a slowdown in credit growth that may improve loan yield through a better loan mix.

tickerNews.title: SIDO plans share buyback up to Rp300 billion
tickerNews.content: - SIDO: The herbal and pharmaceutical company Sido Muncul plans to buy back approximately 450 million shares (1.5% of its capital) with a funding allocation of up to Rp300 billion. The maximum buyback price is capped at Rp760 per share, and the buyback period will run until 2 May 2026. The plan will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders meeting on 2 May 2025.

tickerNews.title: PT Kreasi Jasa Persada increases stake in PTRO to 43.519%
tickerNews.content: - PTRO: Petrindo Jaya Kreasi (CUAN) through its subsidiary PT Kreasi Jasa Persada purchased about 105.2 million Petrosea shares at an average price of Rp2,947 per share on 14 March 2025. The transaction value was roughly Rp310 billion. After the transaction, PT Kreasi Jasa Persada’s ownership in PTRO rose from 42.476% to 43.519%.

tickerNews.title: TPIA targets four‑fold revenue growth in 2025
tickerNews.content: - TPIA: Director of Chandra Asri Pacific, Edi Rivai, said the company targets revenue growth of up to four times in 2025, driven by the contribution of Shell Energy and Chemicals Park (SECP) in Singapore, which is expected to be finalized in the second quarter of 2025. The target assumes the SECP acquisition is completed by Q2 2025. Edi also stated that the company allocated capex of Rp8.8 trillion in 2025 to start construction of a chlor‑alkali‑ethylene dichloride (CA‑EDC) plant valued at a total of Rp15 trillion. The plant, designated as a National Strategic Project, will produce more than 400,000 tons of caustic soda (sodium hydroxide) per year and 500,000 tons of ethylene dichloride annually.

tickerNews.title: INDY to invest $10 million as cornerstone investor in Nanshan Aluminium IPO
tickerNews.content: - INDY: Indika Energy, through its subsidiary PT Perkasa Investama Mineral, plans to participate as a cornerstone investor with a commitment of US$10 million in the IPO of Nanshan Aluminium International Holdings Limited on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The move aligns with INDY’s strategy to reduce reliance on coal‑related activities.

tickerNews.title: AVIA raises selling price by 1‑2% due to rupiah depreciation
tickerNews.content: - AVIA: Head of Investor Relations at Avia Avian, Andreas Timothy Hadikrisno, said the company increased its selling price by about 1‑2% at the beginning of the year because the rupiah kept weakening while roughly 70% of raw material inputs are imported. Andreas added that the company remains optimistic that the price increase will not erode market share because the price hike was communicated at the start of 2025. Previously, AVIA announced a revenue growth target of 6‑10% YoY for 2025.

tickerNews.title: PBID reports 4Q24 net profit of Rp101 billion, targets 10% revenue growth in 2025
tickerNews.content: - PBID: Panca Budi Idaman recorded net profit of Rp101 billion in 4Q24 (‑14% YoY, ‑23% QoQ), bringing 2024 net profit to Rp485 billion (+30% YoY). Although 4Q24 revenue grew +13% YoY, cost of goods sold (+15% YoY) and operating expenses (+34% YoY) surged, causing operating profit margin to fall to 8.7% in 4Q24 (vs. 11.7% in 4Q23). The rise in operating expenses was driven by a 39% YoY increase in total salary and allowance costs. In 2024, revenue grew +12% YoY while cost of goods sold (+9% YoY) and operating expenses (+13% YoY) grew more moderately, improving overall profit margins. PBID targets revenue growth of +10% YoY in 2025.

tickerNews.title: NSSS director buys 46.6 million shares at Rp240 each
tickerNews.content: - NSSS: Director of Nusantara Sawit Sejahtera, Teguh Patriawan, purchased approximately 46.6 million NSSS shares at Rp240 per share on 12 March 2025. The transaction value was about Rp11.2 billion. After the purchase, Teguh Patriawan’s ownership increased from 10.485% to 10.681%.

tickerNews.title: Techno9 Indonesia plans rights issue of ~2.2 billion new shares
tickerNews.content: Techno9 Indonesia (NINE) intends to conduct a rights issue of approximately 2.2 billion new shares, which could result in up to 50% dilution. The execution price has not been announced, and the proceeds will be used for working capital. The plan will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders meeting on 30 April 2025.

tickerNews.title: Express Transindo Utama resumes taxi operations in Jabodetabek with electric fleet
tickerNews.content: Express Transindo Utama (TAXI) has resumed its taxi services in the Jabodetabek area after suspending conventional taxi operations during the pandemic. The restart is supported by a strategic partnership with PT Rekan Anak Bangsa, a subsidiary of GoTo (GOTO), established in November 2024. Through this collaboration, driver‑less operators can use electric TAXI vehicles via the Gocar app. In December 2024, TAXI began serving the public with BYD M6 electric cars. TAXI’s CEO, Johannes Triatmojo, said the company aims to have at least 24,000 conventional and online taxi units operating in Jabodetabek.
